item.title: Lagos to London | My transition
item.author: Selin Olenik,Daniel Ogbonna,
item.description: I was born and raised in Lagos, the most populated city in Nigeria and in Africa as a whole. On September 30th 2014, less than 3 weeks after my 17th birthday, probably the most defining event in my life so far occurred. I moved to London to attend Imperial College. Before leaving, my parents gave me …

item.title: I’m black and I don’t rap
item.author: Selin Olenik,Chimdi E Igwe,
item.description: I get these questions all the time: “Who’s your favourite rapper?”, “I bet you can freestyle!”, “How can you not love Tupac? You’re black!” Hip-hop for some reason never really appealed to me when I was younger – I didn’t hate it, but I tended not to go out of my way to find it. After moving …

item.title: Professor Hawking visits Imperial
item.author: Selin Olenik,Matthew Johnston,
item.description: Esteemed theoretical physics boffin, Professor Stephen Hawking, gave a lecture on Monday evening, speaking on black holes, Hawking Radiation, and AI. Taking place in a packed Great Hall, Professor Hawking was introduced via a video from The Big Bang Theory’s Sheldon Cooper before launching into his …

item.title: Union screws up autumn elections
item.author: Selin Olenik,Felix Editor,
item.description: Imperial College Union had to remove 73 positions from the Autumn Elections that were underway this week, after a technical error that allowed students to vote twice. The announcement was made on Tuesday afternoon, when Andrew Keenan, head of the student voice and communications, sent out a mass …

item.title: Alice Gast’s autumn letter
item.author: Selin Olenik,Matthew Johnston,
item.description: Imperial College President, Alice Gast, released her autumn letter this week and set out College’s vision for the future, a post Brexit future. The letter touched on the fact that (spoiler alert) Brexit is happening and what the College plans to do to keep the status quo as much as possible. Gast …

item.title: Getting Oily: The science of cooking
item.author: Selin Olenik,Alexandra Lim,
item.description: The latest branch of research is all about oil, specifically the daily occurrence of heating up some olive oil in a pan, something most of us don’t even think about. So you’re in the kitchen, searing that fatty, gorgeous pink salmon, when your friend starts a convenient Facetime session. Next thing …

item.title: Half a century of boldly going...
item.author: Selin Olenik,Anurag Deshpande,
item.description: Fifty years ago, as the spectre of the Cold War loomed over the world and the first battles of the civil rights movement were being fought, a corny, slightly overacted show with bold utopian and egalitarian aspirations made its way onto the prime-time lineup. Trek wore its heart on its sleeve, …

item.title: Government accused of barring foreign expertise
item.author: Selin Olenik,Felix Editor,
item.description: Last week, foreign academics from the London School of Economics (LSE) accused the British Government of excluding them from advisory talks on Brexit. Allegedly, during a meeting between Professor Kevin Featherstone, head of LSE’s European Institute, and Nathaniel Copsey, head of research for the …

item.title: Hunt reveals his NHS plans
item.author: Selin Olenik,Matthew Johnston,
item.description: Jeremy Hunt revealed his new plan for the future of the NHS last week, a mix of creating more British doctors and attempting to keep the ones that are trained here for longer. Currently there’s a cap of 6,000 students attending medical schools country-wide and Hunt plans to raise this by 25%, giving …
